dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: ...so, like, what even is beshbarmak? Well, it's, uh, a really important traditional Kazakh dish, Host_A. Like, super symbolic of hospitality.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beshbarmak is more than just a dish—it is a vital part of Kazakh culture, symbolizing hospitality and family traditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but why is everyone so mad about this one guy's version?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but why is everyone so mad about this one guy's version?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so, this popular blogger, he has, like, 600,000 followers, um, he put out his "creative twist."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so, this popular blogger, he has, like, six hundred thousand followers, um, he put out his creative twist.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A heated debate erupted on social media after a well-known blogger, with over 600,000 followers, shared his own take on the traditional Kazakh dish. While his version of beshbarmak was meant to be a creative twist, it instead caused cultural shock among his Kazakhstani audience.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A creative twist, that's fine, right? People experiment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A creative twist, that's fine, right? People experiment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You'd think, but he, uh, he made some subtle changes. Like, added bay leaves, dill, vinegar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You'd think, but he, uh, he made some subtle changes. Like, added bay leaves, dill, vinegar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The blogger made subtle changes to the classic recipe—he added bay leaves, dill, and vinegar, boiled the noodles in water instead of broth, and topped it all off with potatoes, a move that left many Kazakhstanis in disbelief.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And he boiled the noodles in water instead of broth. And, um, he topped it all with potatoes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he boiled the noodles in water instead of broth. And, um, he topped it all with potatoes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The blogger made subtle changes to the classic recipe—he added bay leaves, dill, and vinegar, boiled the noodles in water instead of broth, and topped it all off with potatoes, a move that left many Kazakhstanis in disbelief.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Potatoes? For noodles? That sounds... different.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Potatoes? For noodles? That sounds... different.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, apparently that was, like, a huge no-no. It sparked outrage, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, apparently that was, like, a huge no-no. It sparked outrage, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, it turned out that all it took to spark outrage was a few unexpected ingredients.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, "traumatic for all Kazakhs" kind of outrage? I saw that comment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, traumatic for all Kazakhs kind of outrage? I saw that comment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Social media users didn’t hold back their reactions. "Sorry, but this is traumatic for all Kazakhs."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Or, "Kazakhs have officially left the chat." It went viral, too, 1.2 million views.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Or, Kazakhs have officially left the chat. It went viral, too, one point two million views.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: "Kazakhs have officially left the chat." ... The video quickly went viral, amassing over 1.2 million views and more than 2,700 comments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So it's like, uh, how Italians feel about weird pizza, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So it's like, uh, how Italians feel about weird pizza, then?

dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! Some even said it was like making borscht without beets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! Some even said it was like making borscht without beets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: "This is like making borscht without beets!" they commented.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But some people were okay with it, right? I think I saw that too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But some people were okay with it, right? I think I saw that too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a few were, like, "Calm down, he's making it his way." Or, "at least the homemade noodles look great!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a few were, like, Calm down, he's making it his way. Or, at least the homemade noodles look great!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: "Calm down, people! He’s making beshbarmak the way he likes it! It looks amazing and probably tastes great!" ... "Beshbarmak or not—who cares? At least the homemade noodles look great!"

dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, is it still beshbarmak if you change it that much?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, is it still beshbarmak if you change it that much?

dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, the majority, you know, they'd firmly say, "this is not beshbarmak!" It's really about tradition.
